headline.main: NASA DENIES CONCEALING EVIDENCE IN DISCLOSURES ON ASTRONAUT'S DEATHS By PHILIP M. BOFFEY

results.snippet: On July 17 the space agency cited evidence that the Challenger crew members had been unaware of the disaster unfolding about them, but it acknowledged today that at that time some key officials had known for almost a week that the astronauts had...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: On July 17 the space agency cited evidence that the Challenger crew members had been unaware of the disaster unfolding about them, but it acknowledged today that at that time some key officials had known for almost a week that the astronauts had activated their emergency breathing packs. But officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration complained at a press briefing that they had been taking a ''very bum rap'' in news reports and editorials that have suggested the agency was deliberately concealing information about the last moments of the seven astronauts, who died when the space shuttle broke up shortly after launching Jan. 28. The officials said that in sensitive matters involving how the crew died, they have consistently tried not to discuss isolated pieces of evidence. The agency said in a statement today that all important evidence was communicated first to the families of the dead crew members, and then, once the investigation of the cause of death was complete, to the public.

headline.main: EXCERPTS FROM SHUTTLE PANEL'S HEARING ON DISCLOSURE OF MEMOS ON FLAWS

results.snippet: Following are excerpts from the transcript of a closed hearing Feb. 10 by the Presidential commission that investigated the loss of the space shuttle Challenger. The article in The New York Times referred to by the chairman was published Feb. 9 and...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the transcript of a closed hearing Feb. 10 by the Presidential commission that investigated the loss of the space shuttle Challenger. The article in The New York Times referred to by the chairman was published Feb. 9 and reported that internal space agency memorandums had warned that flaws in the booster rocket seals could cause a catastrophic accident. WILLIAM P. ROGERS, chairman of the commission: I think it goes without saying that the article in The New York Times and other articles have created an unpleasant, unfortunate situation. There is no point in dwelling on the past. The important thing is to be sure that the commission has all the appropriate documents and all the appropriate information. It may well be that we have all learned a lesson from this, that as much as possible we would hope that NASA and NASA's officials will volunteer any information in a frank and forthright manner. We don't want to be in a position that we have to ask for everything in advance.

headline.main: WHEN THE SLUSH PILE COMES TO LIFE

results.snippet: We expect a lot from television; it is supposed to amuse, inform, edify and entertain.   Sometimes it does one or more of these things, giving us three out of four. Ocassionally, it hits a grand slam. Mostly, however, television is just there,...
results.lead_paragraph: We expect a lot from television; it is supposed to amuse, inform, edify and entertain. Sometimes it does one or more of these things, giving us three out of four. Ocassionally, it hits a grand slam. Mostly, however, television is just there, whiling away the hours. The medium devours new material; its appetite is insatiable, and it is no good saying that television should be better than it is. Television already is what it is, and there is not, and never will be, enough good new material to go around. The Emmy nominations, recently announced, went to those programs you expected them to go to: 16 for ABC's ''Moonlighting'' at the top of the list, with NBC's ''The Cosby Show'' and ''The Golden Girls'' each getting 15. At the same time, for ABC to find a ''Moonlighting,'' it had to commission and then reject numerous other programs. These programs, usually not shown, are the equivalent of a magazine's slush pile. On ABC tonight, the slush pile comes to life.

results.snippet: International    Sudanese rebels shot down a plane operated by Sudan Airways carrying 60 people, the Sudanese Government reported. There was no immediate official casualty toll, but reports reaching Cairo from Khartoum, the Sudanese capital,...
results.lead_paragraph: International Sudanese rebels shot down a plane operated by Sudan Airways carrying 60 people, the Sudanese Government reported. There was no immediate official casualty toll, but reports reaching Cairo from Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, indicated there were no survivors. The attack came one day after rebel forces threatened to shoot down all planes flying over the areas they control in the southern provinces. [ Page A1, Column 3. ] Chile's leader rejected proposals of a high-level Reagan Administration envoy for substantial improvements in Chile's human rights record and the start of a political transition to democracy, Administration officials said. As a result, the officials said, the United States is weighing economic steps against Chile and is seeking to increase pressure on Gen. Augusto Pinochet out of concern that the absence of political change is leading to widening terrorist activity. [ A1:1. ]

headline.main: RENAMING FOR A HERO IS DISPUTED

results.snippet: Little Tokyo, the normally placid Japanese neighborhood in the shadow of City Hall, is divided by a rare public squabble over Mayor Tom Bradley's proposal to rename Weller Street in honor of Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka, the Challenger astronaut....

byline.original: By PAULINE YOSHIHASHI, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Little Tokyo, the normally placid Japanese neighborhood in the shadow of City Hall, is divided by a rare public squabble over Mayor Tom Bradley's proposal to rename Weller Street in honor of Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka, the Challenger astronaut. Lieutenant Colonel Onizuka, who died with his six fellow crew members in the shuttle explosion Jan. 28, was the first Asian-American astronaut and is regarded as a hero by Japanese-Americans. His photograph hangs in the shops and offices of dozens of his friends in this neighborhood, which is bordered by Los Angeles, Alameda, First and Third streets in the southeast corner of the downtown section. The dispute pits most Little Tokyo businessmen and community leaders, who favor the name change, against a handful of merchants on Weller Street, which is a block long and is lined by fashionable stores and restaurants that cater to Japanese tourists.

headline.main: NASA Has Been Telling the Truth All Along

results.snippet: To the Editor:   In your July 30 editorial ''Nobility, and Knowledge, in Space,'' you state that NASA ''has forgotten how to tell the exact truth.'' ''Yet especially when disaster strikes,'' you say, ''that's the best way, indeed the only way for...
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In your July 30 editorial ''Nobility, and Knowledge, in Space,'' you state that NASA ''has forgotten how to tell the exact truth.'' ''Yet especially when disaster strikes,'' you say, ''that's the best way, indeed the only way for an agency to maintain the public's trust. Tell everything you know, as soon as you know it, and be the first to admit error if you turn out to be wrong.''

headline.main: FLAVORS OF ICE-CREAM PARLORS: NOSTALGIC TO NEW

results.snippet: TWO years before the Declaration of Independence, in 1774, a New York confectioner - last name Lenzi, first name unknown - helped set off a revolution of another kind: he announced that his store would be selling ice cream. Since then, ice-cream...

byline.original: By FRAN R. SCHUMER; Fran R. Schumer, whose newest book, ''Most Likely To Succeed'' (Random House), will be published in January, knows New York through its neighborhood delis and luncheonettes

results.lead_paragraph: TWO years before the Declaration of Independence, in 1774, a New York confectioner - last name Lenzi, first name unknown - helped set off a revolution of another kind: he announced that his store would be selling ice cream. Since then, ice-cream parlors have experienced boom and bust, but the species endures. Snuggling up with a pint in front of the video-cassette recorder has its pleasures, but many people prefer to sip their sodas in public, on a stool, with the ineffable smell of chocolate and happiness. Naturally, the species has had to adapt. It sells sandwiches. It accepts heresies such as mashed-up cookies. It even goes in for aberrations, including a concoction called Astronaut (freeze-dried ice-cream crystals). But in essence the ice-cream parlor remains what it always was, a monument to decadence, languor and the insatiable American sweet tooth.

headline.kicker: THE FLAVORS OF ICE-CREAM PARLORS: NOSTALGIC TO NEW

results.snippet: T HE classic among old-fashioned parlors is Eddie's Sweet Shop in Forest Hills, Queens. If ever there was an Eddie, he is no more. For the last 18 years, the shop has been run by Joe Citrano with the help of his father, Vito, 77 years old, and son,...

byline.original: By FRAN R. SCHUMER; Fran R. Schumer, whose newest book, ''How To Succeed'' (Random House), will be published in January, knows New York through its neighborhood delis and luncheonettes

results.lead_paragraph: T HE classic among old-fashioned parlors is Eddie's Sweet Shop in Forest Hills, Queens. If ever there was an Eddie, he is no more. For the last 18 years, the shop has been run by Joe Citrano with the help of his father, Vito, 77 years old, and son, Vito, 19. Everything is homemade: whipped cream, chocolate syrup and divine hot fudge. Mr. Citrano refuses to adulterate his ice cream with mashed-up candy bars or cookies. The shop boasts the original appointments: cast-iron ceiling, stained-glass windows and tile floors. Eddie's Sweet Shop, 105-29 Metropolitan Avenue, Queens, 718-520-8514. Tuesday through Friday, 1 to 11:30 P.M.; Saturday and Sunday, noon to 11:30 P.M.

results.snippet: A leak of liquid oxygen from a fuel system has forced a third delay in the launching of a $37.3 million weather satellite.   The launching of the satellite aboard an Atlas-E booster, which had been scheduled for last Friday at Vandenberg Air Force...
results.lead_paragraph: A leak of liquid oxygen from a fuel system has forced a third delay in the launching of a $37.3 million weather satellite. The launching of the satellite aboard an Atlas-E booster, which had been scheduled for last Friday at Vandenberg Air Force Base, 140 miles northwest of Los Angeles, has been reset for Sept. 7, according to Jim Elliott, a spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The space agency is responsible for placing the satellite into orbit for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

headline.main: The Law and the Last Frontier

results.snippet: Suppose you were an American citizen who lived in outer space and you invented a new gadget, a widget of the future.   Would it be protected under United States patent laws?   If you accidentally dropped your invention and it flew, or floated, into...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Suppose you were an American citizen who lived in outer space and you invented a new gadget, a widget of the future. Would it be protected under United States patent laws? If you accidentally dropped your invention and it flew, or floated, into the face of a compatriot or someone who was not an American, would you be liable for the medical bills? Congress thinks it is time to discuss these questions now.

headline.main: Suppose a Briton Assaults a Yank

results.snippet: Excerpts from the report by Congress's Office of Technology Assessment, ''Space Stations and the Law: Selected Legal Issues'':    Suppose the United States and Great Britain jointly own a space station but maintain separate jurisdiction and control...
results.lead_paragraph: Excerpts from the report by Congress's Office of Technology Assessment, ''Space Stations and the Law: Selected Legal Issues'': Suppose the United States and Great Britain jointly own a space station but maintain separate jurisdiction and control over their separate space modules. Now, further suppose that a British astronaut assaults a U.S. astronaut while the U.S. astronaut is in the British module.

headline.main: Los Angeles Panel Votes A Street for Astronaut

results.snippet: A City Council committee voted Tuesday to rename a Little Tokyo street for Ellison S. Onizuka, the shuttle astronaut who perished in the Challenger disaster, rejecting arguments by merchants that the change will hurt their businesses.   The...
results.lead_paragraph: A City Council committee voted Tuesday to rename a Little Tokyo street for Ellison S. Onizuka, the shuttle astronaut who perished in the Challenger disaster, rejecting arguments by merchants that the change will hurt their businesses. The two-member panel agreed to change Weller Street, a block-long street lined by stores and restaurants that cater to Japanese tourists, to Onizuka Street.

results.snippet: A former American astronaut, James B. Irwin, said he was detained most of today by local Turkish policemen after allegations that he engaged in espionage while searching for Noah's Ark. He denied the charge.
results.lead_paragraph: A former American astronaut, James B. Irwin, said he was detained most of today by local Turkish policemen after allegations that he engaged in espionage while searching for Noah's Ark. He denied the charge.

headline.main: THE DIFFERENT BEATS ALONG DIFFERENT STREETS

results.snippet: THE bad news for campaigning politicians and other parade lovers is that the Labor Day Parade - which has been with New Yorkers off and on since 1882 - has been canceled this year. Thomas Van Arsdale, the new head of the New York City Central Labor...
results.lead_paragraph: THE bad news for campaigning politicians and other parade lovers is that the Labor Day Parade - which has been with New Yorkers off and on since 1882 - has been canceled this year. Thomas Van Arsdale, the new head of the New York City Central Labor Council, decided not to ask union members to show the flag ''on a holiday they could spend at the beach.'' But if the trade unionists are not marching tomorrow, nearly everyone else in town continues to do so on one day or another. The green stripe on Fifth Avenue for the St. Patrick's Day parade, which dates back to colonial times but has had its format as an Irish Catholic New York institution since the 1850's, now is privately sponsored, no longer a municipal perk. There is not sufficient chromatic spectrum in city paint buckets to accommodate each of the ethnics that have been on the march since then. The West Indians and the Norse, in Brooklyn, do it. The Puerto Ricans and the Irish, of course, do it. The homosexuals and celebrants of Halloween (in Greenwich Village) do it. The Greeks, the Irish and the Jews; the military, those with pacifist views - all do it.
